free_text.Learning outcomes: [8]The goal of this class is to introduce the students to the principles of digital signal processing. The course studies discrete-time signals and systems which have become the basis for modern digital signal processing. It develops the principles behind most modern signal processing techniques.  The tentative course contents are given below.
free_text.Content: [8][b]1 Basic discrete-time signals and systems[/b][br/][li]Signal classes and operations on discrete-time signals[br/][li]	Signals as vectors in Hilbert space[br/][b]2 Fourier Analysis[/b][br/][li]	Properties of Fourier transforms.[br/][li]	The FFT.[br/][b]3 Discrete-Time Systems[/b][br/][li]	LTI filters.[br/][li]	Convolution and modulation.[br/][li]	Difference equations.[br/][li]	FIR vs IIR, stability issues.[br/][b]4 Z-transform[/b][br/][li]	Properties and regions of convergence.[br/][li]	Applications to linear systems.[br/][b]5 Filter Design[/b][br/][li]	FIR design methods.[br/][li]	IIR design methods[br/][li]	Filter structures.[br/][b]6 Stochastic Signal Processing[/b][br/][li]	Random processes.[br/][li]	Spectral representation.[br/][b]7 Interpolation and Sampling[/b][br/][li]	Continuous-time paradigm.[br/][li]	Interpolation.[br/][li]	Sampling theorem, Aliasing.[br/][b]8 Quantization[/b][br/][li]	A/D and D/A converters.[br/][b]9 Multi-rate signal processing[/b][br/][li]	Upsampling and downsampling.[br/][li]	Oversampling.[br/][b]10 Multi-dimensional signals and processing[/b][br/][li]	Introduction to Image Processing.[br/][b]11 Practical applications[/b][br/][li]	Digital communication system design.[/8]
free_text.Bibliography and material: [8]Textbook : Signal processing for Communications, EPFL Press, 2008, by P. Prandoni and M. Vetterli[br/]Recommended reading : Discrete-Time Signal Processing, Prentice Hall, by Alan V. Oppenheim, Ronald W. Schafer, John R. Buck.
free_text.Required prior knowledge: [8]Circuits and systems, basic probability course, analysis and linear algebra

free_text.Objectifs d'apprentissage: [8]Le cours  introduit les principes numériques de traitement des signaux. Il étudie les signaux et systèmes en temps discrets qui sont devenus les bases des techniques du traitement des signaux numériques modernes.  Il développe les principes derrière la plupart des techniques du traitement de signaux.[/8]
